title: redirect unexpected behavior
'express --help' displays wrong in 3.0.0beta7
body:
There is a problem with Commander outputting the default usage showing that it can use '-h', yet Hogan has explicitly set '-h' to be used for itself. This is an issue with Commander, since it uses the 'help' default and I don't know if there's an easy way to override this and keep compatibility with Commander. I'd think a ticket needs to be opened in Commander, where a '-h' needs to be checked if it's in use first, before printing out the usage view.

```
new-host-3:bin james$ ./express --help

  Usage: express [options]

  Options:

    -h, --help          output usage information
    -V, --version       output the version number
    -s, --sessions      add session support
    -e, --ejs           add ejs engine support (defaults to jade)
    -J, --jshtml        add jshtml engine support (defaults to jade)
    -h, --hogan         add hogan.js engine support
    -c, --css <engine>  add stylesheet <engine> support (less|stylus) (defaults to plain css)
    -f, --force         force on non-empty directory

new-host-3:bin james$ ./express -h
destination is not empty, continue? no
aborting
new-host-3:bin james$
```

title: EventEmitter memory leak with successful sendfile
body:
If sendfile is successful, the socket error listener doesn't get removed.
This leads to an EventEmitter memory leak (source: [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11605634/nodejs-express-set-server-possible-eventemitter-memory-leak-detected/11628001#11628001)):

```
 (node) warning: possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners() to increase limit.
Trace: 
    at Socket.<anonymous> (events.js:139:15)
    at ServerResponse.sendfile (/data/www/margintop/server/node_modules/express/lib/response.js:185:14)
    at /data/www/margintop/server/webserver/webserver.js:17:9
    at callbacks (/data/www/margintop/server/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:165:11)
    at param (/data/www/margintop/server/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:139:11)
    at pass (/data/www/margintop/server/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:146:5)
    at Router._dispatch (/data/www/margintop/server/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:173:4)
    at Object.router [as handle] (/data/www/margintop/server/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:33:10)
    at next (/data/www/margintop/server/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/proto.js:190:15)
    at multipart (/data/www/margintop/server/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/middleware/multipart.js:52:61)
```

title: Fixes path joining in app stub generator on win32 systems
body:
This is a rather trivial pull request to ensure that on win32 systems express.js stubs that are created via `express` command line can be started out of the box.

Instead of using a simple string concatenation

```
    app.use(express.static(__dirname + '/public'));
```

the path for static middleware is built via a path.join

```
    app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public')));
```

title: view and static broken since using connect-vhosts
Allow more granular control over JSONP
body:
Proposed changes for #1240.  This adds an options argument to `Response.json()`:

```
res.json([status,] object[, options]);
```

Options are:

```
{
    jsonp: Boolean, // enable or disable JSONP output for this response
    jsonpCallbackName: String, // query string parameter to use for callback name
    jsonReplacer: Function || Array, // the replacer to send to JSON.stringify
    jsonSpaces: Boolean // tell JSON.stringify to pretty print
}
```

Each of these options overrides the corresponding global option.  If any option is omitted, we fall back to the global setting.

title: Allow more granular control over JSONP
body:
Currently, the ability to allow JSONP is a global app setting.  There's no way to control whether a specific route allows JSONP other than deleting `req.query.callback` (or in 3.x, whatever you've set `jsonp callback name` to).

Consider an app that has routes where we want to allow public access (from other origins) and "private" APIs (routes that should **not** be accessible from other origins).  We should be able to explicitly enable/disable JSONP, rather than the rather [hacky method](http://stackoverflow.com/a/11597331/201952) of _globally enabling_ JSONP and then deleting query params to turn it off for specific routes.  (This leaves the door open to forgetting to disable JSONP on a new, private route.)

title: CSRF Route Exemption Settings (e.g. app.set('csrf exemptions', [routes])
body:
We should add CSRF route exemption settings so we don't have to manually copy `csrf.js` found here:

And then make a kludge (e.g. `if (req.path === '/paypal/callback')`).

title: Skipping Route Middleware
body:
I found this post ( https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!topic/express-js/pVAhabtG04k ) about next( true ), but it seems you got around to removing it.

I want to use middleware for getting locals, but I don't need to get several locals for a route if req.xhr is set.

This is my original (naive) approach (in CoffeeScript):

```
    app.get "/", ( req, res, next ) ->
        if req.xhr
            res.render "index"
        else
            user = req.session.user

            if not user?
                next new Error( "You must be logged in to view this page." )

            async.parallel (
                featured: featured
                categories: categories
                received: ( callback ) ->
                    received user.id, callback
                sent: ( callback ) ->
                    sent user.id, callback
            ), ( err, result ) ->
                if err
                    next err
                else
                    locals = result
                    res.render "index", locals

```

But what I want to do is:

```
    xhrCheck = ( req, res, next ) ->
        if not req.xhr
            next( true )
        else
            next()

    app.get "/", xhrCheck, exposeFeatured, exposeCategories, exposeSent, exposeReceived

    app.get "/", ( req, res, next ) ->
        res.render "index"
```

Is there a way to implement this that I am unaware of?

title: Support removing routes
body:
We're doing some dynamic route creation to handle cross site callbacks. As such we build up a lot of routes that are really one hit wonders. Came across this gem of a monkey patch to hack in route removal.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10378690/remove-route-mappings-in-nodejs-express

Anyone interested having this bundled into a pull request? If so syntax preferences? Happy to add but don't want to if it's not going to be accepted.

Thanks,
Kav

title: More specific error objects
body:
Does anyone else think it would be a good idea to have error objects specific to the various error that can possibly arise from the Express framework?

We could have a ViewNotFound type that could be sent when a view is not found instead of just a regular Error object. In which case we could just do an 'instanceof' on the error object to identify and handle common errors.

Another way to do it would be to assign to the 'number' property of the Error object and provide constants that represent common errors.

title: Use of parent path '..' in res.download does not resolve
body:
When using parent path representation in res.download, only paths without the parent path notation allowed the file to be downloaded.  

For example I have a file at the following location on my server:

/home/node/site/public/images/image.png

My node server runs in:
/home/node/site/node

And in a controller, I create this file as follows:
/home/node/site/node/controllers/../../public/images/image.png

However, when I try to send this file for download via res.download, it does not download when written like:
res.download(/home/node/site/node/controllers/../../public/images/image.png);

Using the actual path to the image without the parent directory notation like this works:
res.download(/home/node/site/public/images/image.png);

Having the parent directory notation is important as I pull the actual path of my server via __diname which gives me:
home/node/site/node/controllers at the current file path.

title: Obtain X-Forwarded-For header from req object
body:

We're then accessing the IP, using `req.connection.remoteAddress`, but this still shows the stingray IP.  Is there a different attribute we should use to obtain the X-Forwarded-For value?

Thank you!

title: Hi! I fixed some code for you!
body:
Hi!

I am migrationBot!

Did you know that `path.{exists,existsSync}` was moved to `fs.{exists,existsSync}`,  and that `process.stdin.setRawMode(mode)` was moved to `tty.ReadStream#setRawMode()` (i.e. `process.stdin.setRawMode()`)  in node v0.8.0? Read more @[API changes between v0.6 and v0.8](https://github.com/joyent/node/wiki/API-changes-between-v0.6-and-v0.8) 

I automatically made some changes I think will help you migrate your codebase to node v0.8.0, please review these changes and merge them if you feel they are useful, If they are not you can ignore this Pull Request.

Have a Nice Day!

--[migrationBot](https://github.com/blakmatrix/node-migrator-bot)

title: Circular Express reference in createServer()
Extending http.IncomingMessage.prototype can cause unexpected behaviour
body:
I've noticed some strange behaviour when attempting to create and run two Express server instances within my app. The two instances are:
1. The main application server I use to server my app's pages
2. The [Kue](https://github.com/LearnBoost/kue) job management UI

These servers each run on their own port and depend on their own version of Express. 

I recently updated my app to use Express 2.5.11 and Kue 0.4.0 (which itself depends on Express 2.5.10). 

Express 2.5.10 contained a bug, which was fixed in [this commit for 2.5.11](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/commit/2968bb00b5a2d15dbda82c5a044ec2afefbcc1e1), which caused a stack overflow when attempting to call `res.redirect()`.  

The odd thing is, when I run my app, I find that I'm still seeing the stack overflow happening for pages rendered by my main application server which is on Express 2.5.11. However, when I temporarily remove the code which starts Kue's server, it works as expected.

Having done a bit of digging, I determined that it is essentially happening for the following reasons:
- Express extends the `http.IncomingMessage` prototype in [request.js](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/2.x/lib/request.js) with a bunch of additional methods. 
- I believe that because `http` is part of the Node API (and not a dependency specific to a given version of Express), extending the `http.IncomingMessage` prototype in this way does so globally, for all consumers of `http.IncomingMessage`. 
- Therefore, if you happen to have two or more versions of Express in your dependency graph, then whichever gets loaded last will end up determining how the `http.IncomingMessage` prototype behaves for all of them. In other words, manipulating the prototype in this case, although an elegant technique, seems to be breaking the isolation of dependencies from one another. 

In my case, the buggy stack overflow behaviour from Express 2.5.10 was replacing the fixed behaviour from 2.5.11 simply because it was loaded second. Obviously I can work around my specific instance of the problem by using a different version of Kue, but I'm more interested in getting a resolution to the deeper problem.

Does this sound like a reasonable analysis? Is there scope for replacing the prototype-extension approach whilst keeping the request API fixed?

Thoughts appreciated.

title: Route fixing:* immediately after :param would become not greedy

body:
This is to follow GNU coding stadards. See:
www.gnu.org/prep/standards/html_node/Standard-Targets.html

title: * after :param is no more greedy
body: for example GET /user/:id*, \* become not greedy, currently if you pass GET /user/123 it'll consume "23", and with this commit it'll only consume the optional trailing "/" and beyond

title: "Error: Router#get() requires a path" in Express 3
body:
I am developing a new app with Express 3 and node.js 0.8. I used the same boilerplate code that I used for my express 2.x app, and just changed the `app.locals.use` stuff.

However, when I try to run my app, the server chokes on this line:

``` coffeescript
app.get '/', (req, res) ->
    res.render 'index'
```

Which, you have to agree, is actually quite normal. I have changed `app.get '/'` to `app.route 'get', '/'`, and I still get this error:

```

DEBUG: Error: Router#get() requires a path
    at Router.route (./node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:267:20)
    at Function.methods.forEach.app.(anonymous function) (./node_modules/express/lib/application.js:412:31)
    at methods.forEach.app.(anonymous function) (./node_modules/express-namespace/index.js:53:14)
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at Function.methods.forEach.app.(anonymous function) (./node_modules/express-namespace/index.js:52:12)
    at Function.app.namespace (./node_modules/express-namespace/index.js:31:6)

title: route middleware dependencies
body:
Allows you to specify dependencies between route middleware, so that function X is always executed before function Y.

load_context = (req, res, next) ->
   .....
   next()

is_signed = 
   before: load_context
   execute: (req, rex, next) ->
       ...
       next()

specifying is_signed as a route middleware is now similar to [load_context, is_signed]..however, the dependency that is_signed has on load_context is cleanly part of the is_signed definition.

title: partials do not work with node v0.8.0
body:
whenever I try to use partials (in express directly or inside of ejs) they do not render into the source and as a result, the site does not work. Is there a workaround for this or a fix coming soon to express?

Thanks

title: res.json does not send json when a status is specified
provide a way to configure what the jsonp callback keyword should be
body:
Right now when you enable jsonp support with

```
app.set('jsonp callback', true);
```

This makes `&callback=foo` work. It would be nice to be able to use other words instead of callback (for whatever reason the user might want). This could be done with

```
app.set('jsonp callback', 'jsonp');
```

This would now allow `&jsonp=foo`

title: Adds multiple view directory handling
body: The code in this commit allows express to retrieve view files from multiple directories.  The existing `options.root` parameter is maintained for compatibility.  All tests pass.

title: 404 handling and low precedence static file handling
body:
Hi,

I'm trying to implement a global 404 route and at the same time catch some static file paths.

I have a static route handler
app.get('routetostatic.pdf', function(req, res){//increment something}
&
I have the following route as the last route added
app.get('*', function(req, res){//do 404 stuff}

Depending on the order of the following middleware I can get one or the other to work but alas not both.
app.use(app.router);//this first static route handler works
app.use(gzippo.staticGzip(server_root + '/public'));//this first global 404 works

Is there a way?

Static cache causes header duplication

Hi, I use Express 3.0 with staticCache and max-age set to one hour. The thing is that the cache saves all headers but change all letters to lower case. When the data from the cache are served, there is the X-Powered-By header twice (once with big first letters and one with all letter lowercase)

X-Powered-By    Express
X-Cache HIT
x-powered-by    Express
...

Hello,

I'm using Expressjs and a stingray load balancer.  The load balancer is handling SSL.  This is setup on HTTP within the stingray appliance.   Because of this, Expressjs does not know if the connection is encrypted or not.    Is there anyway to obtain the protocol from the request object?

title: encoding passed variable in ejs template
Template engine errors with alternate extensions
body:
Creating a custom module (for using plates as an express template engine)

``` javascript
  app.set('view engine', 'fastfood');
```

Since plates is not a template language, it requires the ability to load code (coffee, js) which loads a bare bones template which is modified by the view.

There seems to be no way to keep the system from looking for (example) views/index.fastfood and reporting an error before it even gets to the __express function in the module.

It seems to be an issue with lib/view.js, in the View constructor and the function View.prototype.lookup, which only recognizes the engine as the file extension, and returns in the negative if that path doesn't exist.

Which results in an error on line 495 of lib/application.js

title: Connect-flash is not working with Express 3 beta
Redirect Safe to protect from unsafe url
body:
`res.redirectSafe(url)` ensures that the redirection is for `/` paths only. If it is not, then a redirect to `/` is made. 
- Implemented as a **very basic** convenience method to handle open redirection attacks.

title: Added support for safe redirect to dodge open redirection attacks.
body:
Calling redirect as:
`res.redirect(true, url);`
would filter, foreign urls and redirect to `/`.

title: SSL Connection Error
body:
I am just testing out creating a https server with express. Note that I am using 3.0.0beta2 version of express. The summary is that I can't seem to get ssl working with express. I get this error:

**Unable to make a secure connection to the server. This may be a problem with the server or it may be requiring a client authentication certificate that you don't have.**

First I thought maybe there is a problem with my certs, so I recreated them and same thing happened. Then I created a https server without express and everything worked. I have tried all that I can think of, maybe someone here can provide some insight into this issue. 

I uploaded my repo here (https://github.com/sharonjl/ssltest) so you can clone and test it out yourself; contains a **dummy** certificate as well! The repo contains an express generated app, can be run by executing app.js. And a single file named app2.js, which has the non-express implementation of a https server.

title: Cannot access bundled modules
body:
The connect and mime modules that are bundled with express.js cannot be accessed by user code. This means following code has no effect, because it accesses the wrong mime module:

```
require("mime").define({"application/x-web-app-manifest+json": ["webapp"]});
```

I don't think that any modules should be bundled with express.js, but if you do you should make them accessible in some way. Maybe just as `require("express").mime`. Or is it possible to make it accessible as `require("express/mime")` or `require("express.mime")` ?

Currently I need to employ evil hacks to add this mime type to all *.webapp files, which is pretty much a joke. The mime module has a nice infrastructure to define mime types, I refuse to accept that I cannot use it!

title: express 3.0 : res.json(res.locals) won't output my own locals
Strange regex compilation in routes
body:
Express 2.5.9 using `app.all(string, function)`.

The route:
`":ids(x(y|z)+)"`

incorrectly compiles to:
`/^(?:(x(y|z))+)\/?$/i`

The plus operator should be applied to only `(y|z)`, but the operator applies to `x(y|z)` in its entirety.

title: Feature Request: Functional-style routing
body:
I've come to realize that I tend to define routes multiple times. Currently, my routing style goes something like this:

```
userPath = '/user/:slug/:controller?.format?';
app.all(userPath, thisMiddleware, thatMiddleware)
app.get(userPath, anotherMiddleware)
```

It would be helpful if we can define a route, then define the request method afterwards like so:

```
app.path('/user/:slug/:controller?.format?')
  .all(thisMiddleware, thatMiddleware)
  .get(anotherMiddleware)

app.path(anotherPath)
  .all()
  .get()
  .post()
```

Just an idea.

Unless I am missing the proper way to do it, it seems that the simple case of adding a single local with name, value has gone away? I found this pretty useful when setting up locals in various places when I only needed to set a single local.

Any particular reason it was removed? I see res.locals(obj) now, but no way to set a single local (I can pass an object with a single field/value obviously).

title: res.redirect() does not handle Accept headers other than text or html
body:
In the implementation of res.redirect(), res.format() is used to set the body to a short hypertext note, presumably to address the SHOULD requirement specified in RFC 2616 for status codes 301, 302, 303 and 307 in cases where the HTTP request method is not equal to HEAD.

However, if the Accept header requests a MIME type other than those mapped to the extnames 'text' or 'html', the current implementation will throw a 406 error in the call to res.format(), send a response, and then throw another error when res.redirect() tries to set the Location header after the response has been sent.

The specific use case that triggered this was performing a 301 redirect for a request with an Accept header of 'application/json', which the resource being redirected to handles appropriately through content negotiation.

Presumably, a fix would be to either 1) change res.format() to avoid throwing the 406 error in every case, allowing the implementor to specify a default action for the case when when no key in the object supplied to res.format() matches the requested MIME type, or 2) change res.redirect() to address the RFC 2616 SHOULD requirement without using res.format().

In a route using req.get(field) if the field doesn't exist it will return the string 'undefined' instead of undefined.

title: [object Object] in logs coming from routes?
body:
Running 3.0alpha4

I am getting some interesting results in my logs out of express.  Sometimes my routes will return [object Object] instead of the response code, i.e. 200.  

No errors are thrown.  However my client side app acts like it received no data.  I haven't been able to isolate one of these calls on my client to see what it is receiving from the service call yet.

Any Ideas?

What it looks like:

GET /route 200 13ms
GET /route [object Object] 1ms
GET  /route [object Object] 1ms
GET /route [object Object] 1ms
GET /route 200 7ms

title: Easier and coherent IP handling for proxy and non-proxy requests
body:
`req.ip` will now return a string containing the client's IP. Regardless if the client uses a proxy, multiple proxies or none.

I fixed a minor security issue in `req.ips` too.

title: should req getters be memoized ?
Express should make POST data available by default
body:
Currently, you have to explicitly tell express to use the connect middleware before you can access POST data.

I believe that in the spirit of convention over configuration, this should be enabled by default. Express isn't a microframework (it has templating, routing and other stuff), so I think support for basic things like this should be out of the box.

I'm happy to have a go at forking this if it would be accepted :)

Thoughts?

title: express(1) create command duplicates folder
body: the command "express create" just as is, will create a project in the current directory, but will also create a folder named "create" in the current directory as well, with all the assets repeated.
